results.description:
Welcome to Early Bird English, the fun and interesting way to improve your conversation skills early in the day -- without cutting into the rest of your weekend! PLEASE NOTE THIS WEEK'S MEETUP IS ON SATURDAY, NOT SUNDAY!

 Leader Eve will supply plenty to discuss, but feel free to bring along an English-language passage that you have enjoyed or found puzzling. We'll all take a look and discuss what it means.

 Early Bird English is founded on the idea that people learn best when they are enjoying themselves. Each session is quickly paced, friendly, and meant to challenge.

Eve charges a small, non-refundable fee for each session, which helps to cover the cost of the website as well as her preparation.   Please note that the $10 fee DOES NOT cover the cost of coffee! 

http://thejoyofenglish.org/

When we learn with pleasure, we never forget.

-- Alfred Mercier

"Lenovo is one of a growing number of multinationals from the non-Anglophone world that have made English their official language."

-- The Economist, 2/15/14

"A strong vocabulary may be your ticket to side-stepping dementia," says a new study from researchers in Spain.  "...An ample vocab is an indication of robust cognitive reserves, a surplus of neurons that help the brain compensate for memory lapses..." 

-- Prevention, April 2015

"It might have been easier to learn a language years ago, but still, I'm having fun...I was heartened to see, just a month or so ago, a Penn State study suggesting that learning a new language can improve your brain function.  It can, in the researcher's words, 'lead to more graceful aging.'" 

-- Tina Hay, editor, The Penn Stater, March/April 2015

"The average American speaks one language.  Be more than average."

-- magazine ad for Rosetta Stone

results.description:
Twelve of the 35 Catskills Peaks are left entirely untouched by man, in their wild state—there’s not even a trail to the summit! We want to share this deep wilderness experience with you so that you may feel the joy and accomplishment of finding the summit canister and recording your name and achievement for posterity! These two mountains are wild, steep, rugged and beautiful, just like the Devil's Path peaks to the East.


We'll pick you up in your choice of either Brooklyn or Manhattan, feed you breakfast (coffee included!) and delicious lunch, provide great company and knowledge of the area and its' wonders, take plenty of photos, and bring you home with a new experience and a sense of pride. We usually stop for a post-hike congratulatory dinner at a local favorite gastropub along the way back to NYC, depending on how everyone's feeling.

MEETUP MEMBERS GET 35% OFF! Just enter code MUP35 at checkout.

Book this adventure here: http://j.mp/hikenorthdome

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 102nd street and Amsterdam Ave. The entrance gate is located on west101st and Amsterdam ave. 

Directions: 1 train to 103rd St. Also, B or D trains to 103rd St stop

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916


2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

When people hear about meditation, they almost always say that they have either never tried it or they were not able to do it. You may have expected that thoughts were supposed to go away, but when you closed your eyes, more thoughts than ever came up.

We invite you to come and experience how meditation can happen effortlessly with a little attention to our very own breath! The free session will include light yoga, breathing techniques and relaxing meditation and will be led by one of the volunteers of the Art of Living foundation.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

results.description:
Long Beach Ride!!

Hello Team,
Once again it looks like we have Great weather for our ride on Saturday. Due to unexpected travel plans I had to move our Long Beach ride forward to Saturday instead of Sunday. Hopefully it's not too late for you to join us on this Beautiful journey. This ride takes us along water front keeping us cool has we travel through the neighborhoods of Midwood, Sheepshead Bay, Howard Beach, Board Channel, Far Rockaway and Atlantic Beach into Long Beach.

Here are the details:
Saturday, August 1st - Long Beach Journey Ride!!!
Meeting @: Prospect Park ( Parkside & Ocean Ave. entrance).
Time: 8:30am, on the pedals by 9:am.
Distance: 30 miles over mostly flat terrain on mainly bike paths or lanes.
Pace: comfortable 13-15mph *there are some need for speed areas.
Fee:$10 for guidance and support.

There are plenty of restaurants and deli's to satisfy your hunger. I'll probably get a sandwich to enjoy on the boardwalk.

Some other fees might include:
$12 entry fee onto Long Beach itself, the sand!!
$5 lifetime bike permit pass for LIRR & Metro North
$9.50 if you buy ticket at LB station and $16 if you purchase on the train.
The LIRR departs LB 25 minutes after each hour back to Penn Station or Atlantic Ave, Bklyn. And there's also the option to ride back :-))

I'm hoping to have a support vehicle trail us along the way. This will allow us to keep the group together and carry our small backpack with beach items or not. I will confirm back to those who are coming regarding the vehicle.

We are meeting at Prospect Park at the Parkside entrance (Parkside & Ocean Ave.) You can take the 'Q' train to Parkside. Restroom are in the Mc Donald's, also coffee (I know not the best).

If you have any questions reach out, I got you!
Avery
results.name: Long Beach Journey Ride!!!

Once again it looks like we have Great weather for our ride on Saturday. Due to unexpected travel plans I had to move our Long Beach ride forward to Saturday instead of Sunday. Hopefully it's not too late for you to join us on this Beautiful journey. This ride takes us along water front keeping us cool has we travel through the neighborhoods of Midwood, Sheepshead Bay, Howard Beach, Board Channel, Far Rockaway and Atlantic Beach into Long Beach.

Here are the details:
Saturday, August 1st - Long Beach Journey Ride!!!
Meeting @: Prospect Park ( Parkside & Ocean Ave. entrance).
Time: 8:30am, on the pedals by 9:am.
Distance: 30 miles over mostly flat terrain on mainly bike paths or lanes.
Pace: comfortable 13-15mph *there are some need for speed areas.
Fee:$10 for guidance and support.

There are plenty of restaurants and deli's to satisfy your hunger. I'll probably get a sandwich to enjoy on the boardwalk.

Some other fees might include:
$12 entry fee onto Long Beach itself, the sand!!
$5 lifetime bike permit pass for LIRR & Metro North
$9.50 if you buy ticket at LB station and $16 if you purchase on the train.
The LIRR departs LB 25 minutes after each hour back to Penn Station or Atlantic Ave, Bklyn. And there's also the option to ride back :-))

I'm hoping to have a support vehicle trail us along the way. This will allow us to keep the group together and carry our small backpack with beach items or not. I will confirm back to those who are coming regarding the vehicle.

We are meeting at Prospect Park at the Parkside entrance (Parkside & Ocean Ave.) You can take the 'Q' train to Parkside. Restroom are in the Mc Donald's, also coffee (I know not the best).

If you have any questions reach out, I got you!
Avery

Ridgewood Ave. and Oak St.  Ridgewood Coffee Company is right up the street from where we usually start when we start at the Duck Pond.  There are benches outside if you feel like sitting down and there's coffee inside if you're sleepy.  The route is flexible depending on who shows up.   The route will be mostly on sidewalks.


Please bring dimes and/or quarters to park at the meters in Ridgewood.  You can park a little further away from Ridgewood Coffee Company to avoid the meters.

We are going to run this 5 mile route courtesy of Gary:

Thanks Gary.

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
Details:

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation:

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

results.name: 7v7 Easy Saturday Soccer August 1, 2015

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 102nd street and Amsterdam Ave. The entrance gate is located on west101st and Amsterdam ave. 

Directions: 1 train to 103rd St. Also, B or D trains to 103rd St stop

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
**INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS**  

                               NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS!

         NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES 

                                      @ RIVERSIDE Park!

                             See our page on Facebook!:

                        ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQxq4zYJDFg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

We'll play 3 simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 107 & 108 Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

                                        Lion’s Head Tavern


                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
Khosi and Kelly love hiking, so when they asked for a kick-ass veg hike, how could I disappoint? We had soooooooooooooooooooooo much fun last year. Let's do it again!


Important information below. Please read ALL DETAILS!!  :)

Trail:


Time : 3.5 hours hiking (doesn't account for the numerous breaks, lunch, swimming at lake, and possibly getting lost, lol) - expect to be out the whole day

Difficulty:  Moderate -- Great for first timers

Length: 5.5 miles 

We will be able to swim in this gorgeous lake shown below (looks more like a mini beach.) We are hiking to this area, so admission to the lake is free!

TIME:


We will meet at Penn Station (Near the NJ Transit ticket booth, North East Corridor, in front of the Duane Reade) at 8:50am. We'll then take the train to Sloatsburg and catch a quick cab ride from there. Train ride is about 45 mins. The MTA does a lot of subway construction on weekends, so please leave home EARLY. Last year, a girl didn't make it to the train on time and was left behind.

FEES:

Penn Station round trip ticket is $27.00. Short 10 min short cab ride: about $10.00 round trip

WHAT TO WEAR:

• Lightweight, loose-fitting, light-colored clothing (3Ls)

• HIKING BOOTS or CROSS TRAINER - with new soles/ Trail running shoes. If wearing sneakers, please make sure they are sturdy with GOOD traction.

• Bathing suit

• Sunglasses - optional

• A hat

WHAT TO BRING:

• BACKPACK with at least 2 liters of water per person, 


• Food (Lunch and snacks) - e.g. sandwich/ fruits/nuts/ pita/hummus/pretzels etc. 

Please DON'T skimp on the food and Water. Pack lunch, snacks, and drinks for 4 hours on the trail and additional hours out and about. You MUST bring a substantial lunch and enough water


• Bug spray (either bring or wear before hike)

• Sunscreen (either bring or wear before hike)

• Camera - optional

• You can bring breakfast for the 1 hr train ride up. If not, you should eat a good breakfast before you leave home.


If you have any questions at all, please, please TEXT or message me! Don't be Shy. I Love questions, so bring 'em on :)

Also, don't forget to bring a small towel, cash, toilet paper (just in case) Tip: if you freeze your water bottles, it will keep your bag cool.

EVENT TYPE: Class

ADMISSION COST: Free Trail Class 

PLEASE NOTE: 

• (The Class date and the Time is August 1 @ 9am) Click on the link to sign up

• http://www.newyorkbartendingschool.com/trial-class.php

• This event doesn't need a host but if you want a host just request it in the forums.

•   Thank me for this information on this fun class by RSVPing.

• Check out the fun we had last time.

• http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/events/223543406/

DESCRIPTION:

The New York Bartending Schools FREE hands-on bartending class is a great way to learn cocktail recipes and show off you mixology skills on your next party. It is also a great way to see their facilities and talk to their staff, without any sale pressure or obligations. This free 2 hour class will allow you to get behind the bar and experience bartending and mixing drinks first-hand. The First 30 minutes will be demonstration. The next 1 hour and a half will be hands on Cocktails Mixology.

LEVEL: beginner

COCKTAILS: Please note drink menu may change.

Watermelon Slice Cocktail Recipe:
*1 oz  kiwi syrup
*2 oz  lemonade ( slightly concentrated, see note )
*1 ½ oz  vodka
*1 ½ oz  fresh watermelon juice

FIRE FAIRY
* 1 oz Amaretto
* 1/2 oz Absinthe
* 1 can of Red Bull

Crazy Parrot recipe
* 1 1/2 oz Captain Morgan® Parrot Bay coconut rum
* 3/4 oz 151 proof rum
* 2 oz pineapple juice
* 1 1/2 oz cranberry juice

Blueberry Gin
* 2 c. Gin
* 2 c. frozen blueberries
* 1/4 c. sugar zest of 1 lemon
* 2 whole cloves
* 1/2 inch piece of a cinnamon stick

Blue Monday
* 1 1/2 oz vodka
* 1/2 oz Cointreau® orange liqueur
* 1/4 oz Blue Curacao liqueurBlue Monday

REFERENCE:

• https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cocktail&redirect=no

• http://www.yelp.com/biz/new-york-bartending-school-new-york

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

Have an expensive DSLR or mirrorless camera, but are still stuck using it in "Automatic" mode? Learn how to control your camera like a pro at the Love Your Camera - Intro to Photography workshop. 

 This photography course has benefit both to the beginner who is struggling to find the 'ON' switch, to the experienced film photographer looking to make the transition into the world of digital photography. If you're unsure about aperture, shutter, white balance, the histogram, raw vs jpeg and pretty much anything else about your camera, this course is the ideal introduction to your digital camera and stepping stone into beautiful photography.

PRENATAL WALKING & YOGA GROUP IN BROOKLYN, PROSPECT PARK

Join prenatal yoga instructor Sofia and birth doula Kyra for a weekly walk through Prospect Park with a thirty minutes prenatal yoga class at the end of the walk.

The walking moms at 9AM at the entrance of the Brooklyn Public Library. We will start our walk at 9:15AM, which will take around 45 minutes, followed by a 30 minute prenatal yoga session.

If you're unsure about aperture, shutter, white balance, the histogram, raw vs jpeg and pretty much anything else about your camera, this course is the ideal introduction to your digital camera and stepping stone into beautiful photography.

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Festival

ADMISSION COST: Free

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rtdy8UE4ZOk

DESCRIPTION:

Summer Streets is an annual celebration of New York City’s most valuable public space—our streets. On three consecutive Saturdays in August, nearly seven miles of NYC's streets are opened for people to play, run, walk and bike. Summer Streets provides space for healthy recreation and encourages New Yorkers to use more sustainable forms of transportation. In 2013, more than 300,000 people took advantage of the open streets.

Summer Streets is modeled on other events from around the world including Ciclovía in Bogotá, Colombia and the Paris Plage in France. The event is part bike tour, part walking tour, part block party—a great time for exercise, people watching, or just enjoying summer mornings. Passersby are weclome to participate in arts and crafts workshops, listen to musical performances, learn to salsa dance, eat healthy snacks, climb a 25' climbing wall, soar through the sky on a 160' zipline and explore a 179 years voice tunnel.

Held between 7:00 am to 1:00 pm, Summer Streets extends from the Brooklyn Bridge to Central Park, along Park Avenue and connecting streets, with easy access from all points in New York City, allowing participants to plan a trip as long or short as they wish. All activities at Summer Streets are free of charge, and designed for people of all ages and ability levels to share the streets respectfully.

MAP:

ATTRACTIONS:

• Free Food & Free Drinks

• Free The 165' long Zipline

• Free 25’ tall REI Wall Climbing

• Free 9-hole mini-golf course

• Free Bike Rentals

• Experience the Sound Tunnel

• and More

REFERENCE LINKS:

https://www.chashama.org/programs/summer-streets-2015

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

results.description:
PADDLES UP!!  Intro to Dragon Boat Paddling.

Every Saturday we welcome new members to try out this new sport of Dragon Boating. No experience needed; coaching, training and all equipment supplied.

If this is your first time trying this sport out, the cost is free.  If you already attended our " Free intro to Dragon Boating" on May 2nd and May 9th, the cost is $10 per session.  However, the fee is applied to the season membership fee of $75 (mid season rate now) if you become a member of "Team Dragon".  Full time College or High School Student Fee is only $35.  Membership comes with unlimited Dragon Boat practices/training every Thursday 6-8pm, every Saturday 10-12am and all events hosted by the NJ Dragon Boat Club at Lake Parsippany.  The season runs from April to September.

To become a season member, go to njdragonboat.org and complete the online registration.

Come out and give it a try and get a great work out!

Expect to meet new friends and enjoy the beautiful Lake!  Please wear appropriate clothing (no jeans), footwear, and sunblock as you may get a little wet from paddling. Bring a bottle of water to rehydrate. 

Please park on the side streets and not in the boat house parking lot.

Please complete and bring this WAIVER (linked) for each individual.

In the event of inclement weather. Please check this site at 8:30am Saturday morning to see if the event is cancelled.

results.description:
• You're either a wholesale, e-commerce, or a retail business- but customers don’t seem to find you?

• Do you find you are spending time on social media with little or no success?

• Don’t know even where to begin when it comes to promoting your fashion brand on social media? 

If you answered yes to any of the above-you need to take this workshop!

We all know that Social media is here to stay! It has become a key tool in helping businesses build their brands, develop customer loyalty and ultimately attract new customers.  It has to be done! 

For small business owners and solopreneurs, it can be overwhelming to stay on top of the latest trends and develop an effective social media strategy.

Social Media maven, Rekha Krishnamurthi of Creative Business Rules, will join us and show you how can you can create a strong online presence and increase sales with limited time and budget!


Rekha will share with you her tips on how to best leverage your time to create an effective social media strategy in as little as 2 hours a week!

Here's just a few of the topics we'll cover:In this 2-hour workshop you’ll learn the best ways to utilize social media and content marketing strategies.  

You’ll learn about:

* Developing a content strategy that you can use to cross promote on

platforms and generate cross media social traffic

* Blog/social media editorial calendar

* Planning content for holidays, seasons and promotions

* Email marketing

* Facebook advertising (boosted posts vs. increase page likes)

* Benchmarks and analytics

We'll also hold a 30 min Q&A session at the end of our workshop to cover any questions you might have!

Whether you’re an emerging designer, new to the fashion business, or a fashion student thinking of launching your own label, this workshop will give you the practical insight into what to do and what not to do in order to successfully create a social media strategy!

Come join us!

When: Saturday, August 1, 2015


Time: 10:00am-12:30pm

(Q&A will take place at 12pm)


Where:

116 West 23rd Street, Suite 5 (5th floor)

New York, NY. 10011


Cost:  $35

Limited Seats are available so sign up today!

results.description:
We do our summer runs in the morning, because it works better for the school, and it's also cooler in the AMs. Plus, you get to start your day off right! :)

Welcome!


If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we have to be out of the gym by 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later! Don't forget:

* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* You will be asked to sign a waiver for 2014 as we're not a litigious group. If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers an email.

Here are the basic rules we follow for games: 1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 6. Subs will enter the game no later than 6 points in (once one of the teams reaches 6 points). The sub will start the following game. Teams will regulate themselves but let's make sure everyone plays.

See you on the court! B-)

***NOTE***

In an effort for us to reduce overcrowding and to maintain a more accurate estimate of how many people to expect, please sign up online if you intend to play. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. We ask that you please just do not show up unannounced as you will kindly be asked to turned away. Also feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your nails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

results.description:
Join us for a day of Wonder & Excitement. We'll start by visiting The Aquarium, partaking in the amusements of Luna Park and seeing all the sights and sounds that The Boardwalk has to offer. (We might also throw caution to the wind and wade in the surf.)

Aquarium:
$10.75 (Online)
$11.96 (@ Gate)

Luna Park:
$1.00 (Per Credit)
Rides (7-9 Credits)

Boardwalk:
Free

Bring: Sun Screen/Sun Glasses
Lunch: Hot Dogs/Funnel Cake/Soda
(Anything we damn well please...Let's Live, Live, Live!!!)

The New York Aquarium is located on Surf Avenue & West 8th Street in Brooklyn, New York 11224.

Mass Transit
Subway
Take the F or Q train to the West 8th Street station on Coney Island, Brooklyn. Alternatively, take the N or D trains to the Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue Station, then walk two blocks east on Surf Ave. (Stillwell Avenue station is handicap accessible on the F, Q, N, D train)

Buses
Take the B36 to Surf Ave. and West 8th St. Or take the B68 to Neptune Ave. and West 8th St., then walk south along West 8th to Surf Ave.
Please note that other bus routes in Brooklyn, as well as buses from other boroughs, intersect with B36 and B68.

By Car
For Drivers Using GPS
Using a GPS unit to navigate to the Aquarium? To reach our parking lot, please plug the following address into your GPS unit: 602 Surf Ave. Brooklyn, NY 11224.

From Manhattan
Take the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel (I-478) to the Brooklyn-Queens Expwy (I-278 West). Take Exit 22 to the Belt Pkwy East. Take to Exit 7 (Ocean Pkwy). Turn right onto Ocean Pkwy and continue to Surf Ave. to the New York Aquarium.

From Long Island & Queens
Take the Belt Pkwy West to Exit 7B (Ocean Pkwy). Turn left onto Ocean Pkwy and continue to Surf Ave. to the New York Aquarium.

From Connecticut, Westchester County and the Bronx
Take the Hutchinson River Pkwy (I-678) South, over Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, and continue south on I-678 (Whitestone Pkwy) to Van Wyck Expwy. Then take Belt Pkwy West to Exit 7B (Ocean Pkwy). Turn left onto Ocean Pkwy. and continue to Surf Ave. to the New York Aquarium.

From Staten Island
Take the Staten Island Expwy (I-278) East across the Verrazano Narrows Bridge, to Belt Pkwy East to Exit 7S (Ocean Pkwy South). Take Ocean Pkwy to Surf Ave. to the New York Aquarium.

From New Jersey
Take the New Jersey Turnpike to the Goethals Bridge (Exit 13) to the Staten Island Expwy (I-278). Follow the directions from Staten Island (above).

Thrive in the Park was created by a group of friends with a common interest in fitness, clean food, and having a great time.

This is a co-ed adult soccer lesson with Coach Moe. All skill levels are welcome. Bring a ball if you have one.


We will be practicing a variety of skills including dribbling, passing/receiving, feinting, shooting, ball control, positioning, tactical training, etc.

Skill exercises will be alternating with strength/agility exercises.

Small sided games

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Brooklyn Soccer Club activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Brooklyn Soccer Club Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Brooklyn Soccer Club programs or activities.

results.description:
#SUMMERSTREETS - http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/summerstreets/html/about/about.shtml

We'll be running up and down Park Ave. The streets are ours! Along the way you can enjoy music, parkour, and some sort of Recycle-a-Bicycle Photo Booth (?).


Meetup/Hangout – 9:45 am

Whole Foods (Union Square) -- upstairs cafe. Show up a bit early to say hi, chat, and drop off any thing you don’t want to run with: jackets, bags, phones, etc. Somebody will always stay to watch the stuff.

Run – 10:00 am

Run 1 mile, 3 miles, 5 miles, or whatever you want. No pressure and no limits. Totally informal. Lots of different paces for lots of different people. Even walking speed is encouraged!

Brunch – 10:45 am

Whole Foods has ALL THE FOOD. Come get some.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

The exhibition, which includes approximately 150 pairs of sneakers, looks at the evolution of the sneaker from its beginnings to its current role as status symbol and urban icon. Included are works from the archives of manufacturers such as Adidas, Converse, Nike, Puma, and Reebok as well as private collectors such as hip-hop legend Darryl "DMC" McDaniels, sneaker guru Bobbito Garcia, and Dee Wells of Obsessive Sneaker Disorder. The exhibition runs run July 10, 2015 - Oct 4, 2015

For more information

https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/exhibitions/rise_of_sneaker_culture/

FREE Circuit Training Saturdays! A 50-minute non-stop intense workout. You will sweat off the weight, you will burn calories, you will gain muscle. All levels welcome. We vow to never give up on you. For we will do everything in our power to help you reach your goal. We operate in a judgement free zone to facilitate your comfort. We promise you will progress.

This Class consist of running, walking, floor exercise, abdominal  workouts, squats, jumprope, and much more. You always have the option to perform the modified version of any drill! This allows beginners or anyone with a minor injury to comfortable fit right in. Build your strength and endurance to perform the unmodified versions of the drill when you see FIT (pun intended :)!! All while moving to be beat of the music. Bring your family, bring your friends.

Updated April 18th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on Tuesdays/Thursdays and Morningside Park for the weekend games.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]


MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.
results.why: It's a great way to start your Saturday!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916


2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

On August 1, 2015, the New York City Sangat, coordinating with sangats across the country, will be leading a 

<a>National Day of Seva</a>

 (selfless community service) to remember and honor the victims and survivors of the Oak Creek and Charleston tragedies. 

What

: National Day of Seva New York City Project - Morningside Park Clean Up

Who

: You, your family and friends. This is a family-friendly project and we encourage volunteers of all ages to participate.

When

: We will meet at 10:00 am sharp. The project will finish around 1:30 pm.

Where

: Morningside Park entrance at West 117th Street & Morningside Avenue in Manhattan (near Columbia University). 


Additional Details

: Volunteers should wear long pants and bring work gloves (we will have a limited supply of work gloves available). Sunscreen and sun protection is encouraged!

RSVP

: Please RSVP using this link - 

<a>http://bit.ly/2015NYCdayofseva</a>;

 by 

Monday, July 27th,

 so that we can make appropriate accommodations. We are hoping to have 100 volunteers participate, so please share this email with friends and family.

If you have any questions, please email us at 

<a>[masked]</a>

. We look forward to engaging in seva with you!

results.description:
Student Testimonial:

"I have tried many different forms of meditation and yoga over the years. Though I have experienced some positive changes practicing over the years I never felt committed to practice on regular basis. Nan takes it to a whole other level. How and why? All I can say is you have to experience it for yourself. There is power in simplicity,love, and truth. Despite some language barriers(which are minor) You can feel her love and healing energy. Open your mind and see with a different set of eyes. I highly recommend her special Saturday classes." Michelina, Bodhi Meditation class Saturday November 15, 2014

“ My first time today. Nan is very helpful and dedicated. I enjoyed it immensely and I did experience a shift in energy. I feel more alert, relaxed and focused even as I write this testimony. I plan on attending her next class in Freeport." Michelina, Bodhi Meditation class September 17, 2014

“ Very strong healing energy tonight. I got there feeling very tired. I had stomach pain all day, and during the first meditation of the evening it got a lot better. By the end I wasn't thinking about it at all. I left full of energy. ” Pam, Bodhi Meditation class November 22, 2013

“ I didn't realize I would be reaping the benefits of Bodhi Med so quickly after attending only two classes. After my second class I felt even more relaxed. I have insomnia, but after the second session I fell asleep faster and deeper which has not happened for a long time. ” Dee, Bodhi Meditation class September 18, 2013

"I have been attending these classes for three weeks. They are amazing. Nan is wonderful! My energy level is shifting and I am beginning to experience an ongoing sense of well-being with balance and relaxation. Highly recommend!" Kathleen, Bodhi Meditation class October 25, 2013

------------------------------------------------------


Bodhi Meditation is a form of energy healing.


Bodhi Meditation is unique in the following ways


1). It channels universal energy rather than working with what’s within one person. It transcends the genetic and physical limits of just one being by relying and drawing energy from the entire universe.

2). The entire human body is the receiver of this energy. The energy’s effects on the body do not rely on certain meridian paths or pressure points of the body, which are the common requirements for many types of the Qi Gong practices.

Small group meditation sessions. Up to 7 people per meeting

I do Bodhi meditation, a form of energy healing.

If you open your heart and relax your mind you will benefit from this session. Benefit you physically and spiritually.

Seating, we have soft meditation mats and soft chairs whichever makes you feel more comfortable.

The session takes about 30-40 minutes followed by a discussion period. Tell me how you feel and what you felt.

Cost: $10

Regular meditation schedule:

Saturday: 10 - 11 AM

For travel from NYC:

Take the Long Island Railroad (Babylon branch) to Merrick

Location:

Ni Nan Healing Art Center

2326 Merrick Road

Merrick, NY 11566

Tel# [masked]

Have a great day,

Nan

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

I leave you with Master JinBodhi's Golden Words:

(Editor's note: The following phrases were suggested by Master JinBodhi and subsequently introduced to his students as a daily practice. Starting your day by loudly reciting these phrases three times, either all of them or a select few, will bring you energy and joy. Give it a try and experience how uplifted you feel...)

1.Self-Confidence

I am most compassionate.

I am most confident.

I am most tolerant.

I am most courageous.

I keep my word.

I am most punctual.

I can do anything.

2. The Power of Knowledge

I am full of wisdom.

I am most knowledgeable.

I love reading.

I love observing.

I love listening.

I love thinking.

I take decisive action.

3. Life Purpose

 I am a gift from the Universe.

I am most charming.

I am most talented.

I can sing most beautifully.

I like challenge.

I am responsible for my actions.

I will fulfill my life purpose.

4. Cause and Consequence

（not for reading loud）

What you give is what you receive.

Care for others, and you are taken care of.

Smile at others, and they will smile at you.

Treat others with sincerity, and sincerity will be given to you.

Make trouble for others, and trouble will find you.

Frequent generosity begets abundance.

Seek to give, not to be rewarded.

SPECIAL HOST Alan Weiss!

I can't lead a meetup this week, but Alan has voluntered. Alan drives down from CT. to fence with us.  Obviously it would be rude of us to ask him to make this trip if there weren't going to be enough people to make it worth his while. So please RSVP as early as you can.


Cancellations are much more likely in the summer!  A meetup can be canceled because the ground is too wet, rain is predicted, high heat & humidity are predicted, or just because there aren't enough people committed to being there.  PLEASE RSVP, and come if you say you will. I will post cancellations here by 9am on the day.


To find us, enter the park via the entrance opposite the Ethical Culture School (The Ethical Culture School is on the west side of Central Park West) at 63rd and Central Park West.  The "Backup Fencing Spot" is on your right, just inside the entrance to the park.  Soccer kids have been grabbing our "Where We Fence" location pretty steadily, but to find it, follow the paved path in a large arc to your left, (It starts off heading SE and curves around to NW).  The "Where We Fence" location is on the hard packed dirt under the trees. 


We have a very limited amount of equipment to lend. We're willing to share, but if you have your own equipment, please bring it.

It's also a good idea to bring water!

A more detailed map of where we fence in Central Park is here:

https://maps.google.com/maps/ms?msid=212152258049056562883.0004db7dc1516e1da7244&msa=0&ie=UTF8&t=m&z=17&vpsrc=0

- Mike

results.description:
Come for an introduction to Tai Chi and Alexander Technique!

Drop-ins welcome! Your first class is $5.

In this 4-class series, participants will learn the beginning of the Wu-Style Tai Chi form, a 108 sequence of movements. In addition, proper alignment within the form will be learned using the Alexander Technique.  Tai Chi is an excellent way to practice Alexander Technique principles and to learn how to move with ease, relieve tension and to move more gracefully.

Wu Style Tai Chi: is a Chinese martial arts system that uses slow, meditative, deliberate movements to learn a fighting system and healthy body posture. In particular, the Wu System uses a shorter stance to create more power and thrust from the practitioner's base.  Benefits include, pain relief, grace, joint health and stress-relief. 

Form: http://youtu.be/Wpi8WzumE8g

Push-hands: http://youtu.be/TL2s07_oQZA

Alexander Technique: is a system of learning how to move more efficiently. The technique supports self-sufficiency, awareness, ease of movement, and healthy posture. 

classes: Saturdays, 10:30-11:30am:  7/18, 7/25, 8/1,  8/22


RSVP required. 

--

Warmly,

Kai Kleinbard

executive functions coach and Alexander Technique teacher

thebodyliterate.com


The bodyLITERATE is dedicated to supporting executive functions in youth through integrating our coaching/tutoring services with the Alexander Technique. We engender efficient, embodied and joyful learning and academic success in young learners and guide parents to create effective learning systems at home. In addition, we run a research lab through the  bodyLITERATE Incubator, providing opportunities to explore creativity and play within the framework of effective learning.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
We'll vist Riverbank Park, Hamilton Grange, Morris-Jumel Mansion and Highbridge and Swindler Cove parks. About 8 miles and 5 hours, this is a hilly part of Manhattan and we will be walking up and down some some relatively steep inclines.

We'll begin by meeting at the 1 train station at 137th Street, take a walk around Riverbank Park, which juts out into the Hudson River on the top of a sewage plant, walk up the hill to Hamilton Grange, Alexander Hamilton's home, at 141st Street, then north along Edgecomb Avenue through Hamilton Heights and Sugar Hill to the Morris-Jumel Mansion ($10 admission) at 163rd Street, where we will eat our lunch outside in the garden, walk the trails of Highbridge Park and on to the High Bridge, then explore Swindler Cove Park. We'll end at the Dyckman Street stop of the 1 train; the A train is available at Dyckman and Broadway.


Meet: 10:30 a.m. at the 137th Street stop of the 1 train.

Leader: Tom Bergen[masked] [masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for paid annual Shorewalkers members, $3 for non-members, visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

results.description:
Sign Up Here! https://goo.gl/gM5KeB

Join us as we explore what was once the playgrounds of all things gang and mob related on this 2.5 hour walking tour. Stroll through historic downtown neighborhoods as you peer into their dark past. Visit famous sites of killings, movies, and infamous crimes.

Peer into New York's dark past and uncover hidden secrets when you visit places ruled by some of the city's most powerful gangs and mobs. Head to Little Italy, once the heart of a tight community of Italian immigrants, to hear stories about mob activities and visit notorious spots. You’ll also explore the little-known history of the Chinese migration to New York, and the dominance of dangerous street gangs and underground opium dens, as well as the ruthless gangs in the infamous Five Points area, and what became of them. Along the way you’ll stop to see historic sites, sample the local fare and discover hidden stories waiting to be revealed.
results.name: Guided Walk Through History

results.description:
InspiredWordNYC presents a celebration of grassroots literary arts in the New York City borough of Queens - the first annual Queens Lit Fest @ LIC Bar. 

When: Saturday, August 1 and Sunday, August 2, 2015

Time: 11am-5pm both days (open mic sign-up starts @ 11am)

Where: LIC Bar
45-58 Vernon Boulevard
Long Island City, Queens, NY 11101
http://www.licbar.com/

Age Limit: 21+ (must bring valid ID)

Admission: FREE

RSVP now! And please SHARE on social media with the hashtag #QueensNYCLitFest.

Queens Lit Fest Team: Mike Geffner, Megan & Lauren DiBello, Audrey Dimola, Marvin Mendlinger, Nichole Acosta, Valerie G. Keane.

This event is funded in part by Poets & Writers with public funds from the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature.

Mission: to bridge the gap and bring together the diverse Queens literary arts community in one wonderfully classic watering hole in the heart of the borough's booming section of Long Island City; to create a dynamic event that is unpretentious, all-inclusive, and filled with heart, soul, and love.

The Progamming (in 3 areas):

In a gorgeous private room with a real fireplace (not that we'll need it in August LOL), there will be a lengthy open mic of poetry, prose, and spoken word (slots will be filled on a first-come, first served basis and 5 minutes apiece), featured writers (such as longtime Queens Poet Laureate Paolo Javier and newly named QPL Maria Lisella), and showcased Queens-based reading series, groups, and organizations.

In the main bar section, with its antique-wood floors, brick walls, and tin ceiling, there will be plenty of choices of draft beer, single-malt scotch, and well-mixed drinks, as well as Queens-based musicians entertaining you during breaks with spirited acoustic sets.

And in the charming outdoor backyard garden, under the peacefulness of willow trees, there will be much schmoozing and people sharing wares at vendor tables.

*****Vendor tables will go to the first eight people who purchase them via this page, though we reserve the right to reject the offer if we feel the it doesn't fit the spirit of the event. We are looking primarily for booksellers, small presses, literary journals, culture groups and organizations.*****

Please support our efforts with any donation of $1 and up. It will be much appreciated. Anything $50 and up will be considered sponsorship. If you're a sponsor, we will place your name/business name on this page in the order of contribution (from highest to lowest), as well as share your generosity on our various social media channels (which reaches 50,000+).

100% of donations/sponsorship dollars will help defray costs and pay for featured artists.

results.description:
Capote's most famous work is a pioneering exampled of both the "nonfiction novel" and the modern "true crime" story. It retells the story of the 1959 murders of the Clutter family in Kansas by a pair of drifting misfits, Dick Hickock and Perry Smith, and of the subsequent trial and execution of the murders. Capote also uses the polarities of this particular case as the starting point for a larger examination of the values of the late 1950s and early 1960s America; the respectable Clutters are so wholesomely all-American that they could almost have been invented, while Smith and Hickock come over as brutal real life versions of the James Dean "rebel" culture.

The world of the victims is painstakingly and sympathetically reconstructed, but Capote's real interest is in the emotional lives of Perry and Dick, and what might have led them into such murderous excess. Indeed, some argue that Capote was so fascinated by Perry Smith because he saw in him a possible alternative version of himself.

Given that Capote wrote about the crime throughout the trial, it has even been suggested that the final verdicts were conditioned by the way in which his journalism had portrayed the killers. In this light, In Cold Blood offers a larger, more disturbing insight. It embodies a debate about fact, fiction, and the overlaps and differences between ethical responsibilities. 

In Cold Blood was a critical and financial success, though Capote was disappointed it failed to win the Pulitzer. It did, however, receive the Edgar Award for Best Fact Crime

Take Acoustic Guitar Lessons in Central Park
Free Group Lessons Saturdays, May 16th to October 17.


You will learn to read notes, chords and play songs you know and love.  You will have the opportunity to learn:


• Basic info about the guitar
• To read and play chords
• To read and play Rhythm
• Techniques for using the pick
• How play finger style.
• What you learn can be applied to Rock, Blues, Folk, Country,

• Plenty of new songs


Anyone can attend and you don't need to attend all the sessions.  A new breakthrough approach, allows each session to be complete even for people who have no experience playing the guitar. 


And after the lesson (12:30 - 1:30p.m), hang out and network with  people, or go check out the sights in the Park!!

WHAT TO BRING: • Bring your own guitar for these lessons

results.description:
Come and photograph the majestic Grand Central terminal -- capture all of the details in the shadows and highlights with HDR photography! We have special permission to use tripods during this five hour workshop. We have led workshops to photograph the Grand Central terminal with tripods more than a dozen times. 

We will meet at 10:30 am at GCT and shoot from 11am until 5 pm. Some people do not have the stamina for a five hour shoot, there are seats in the food court downstairs and seats in the station master's office where you can rest, or you may leave early (just turn in your permit before leaving)

Meet outside of the station master's office, there is an area to the left of the SMO. The SMO is the customer waiting area with the glass doors on the upper level of the terminal, at the top and just to the right of the escalators on the west side of the building (near tracks 34/35 and the Transit Museum store.

You will be taking 3-10 exposures in order to capture all of the details in the shadows and highlights. Tom and I will be helping you with compositions, checking exposures, etc. For the first hour we are very hands on helping you with your camera settings, interpreting histograms, etc. 

After the first hour we will be shooting too, but will aid you with compositions, answer questions, check in on your exposures, etc. 

Experienced photographers can utilize us for as little or as much assistance as desired. for many of our participants getting the inside scoop on locations and compositions and getting access and being able to use a tripod is reason enough to come with us! We will get you up to speed because we have been there with tripods so many times we know some great compositions!

As always, you must sign sign a liability waiver for this photo tour.

Please note that all of our workshops require the participants sign a liability waiver. Download it here; then print, read and sign it. Some venues may also require a location liability waiver.

See more images here:

results.description:
Do you know nothing about 3D Printing... but are interested in learning more? 

This 4 hour class gives you all info on the basics of 3D printing! It is designed for the complete beginner, and we try to cover tons of basic information to educate you on how and where to continue your learning. We show you plenty of online links too, to offset lecture time. There will be some doughnuts/bagels/coffee. Last time we were able to cover everything in 3.5 hours however in case we run long, we ask for 4 hours of your time. Breaks will be provided in between sessions.

Hour I: Introduction to FDM Printing, understanding how the mechanics of a hot glue gun translate in an xyz plane into making an object. 

Hour 2: What is filament? Discuss why ABS shrinks more than PLA, pass around different Shapeways samples, discuss sandstone, and talk about SLS printers, medical and food printing.

Hour 3: Designing for 3D Printers: Understanding support structures, rafts, HIPS, PVA, mm to inches, and talk about Shapeways and 3D Hubs, and how to get your stuff printed. Discuss using tools, files, sandpaper, finishing.

Hour 4: Thingiverse, downloading other parts, trouble shooting, nightmares of 3D Printing.

[PLEASE NOTE: All minors must be accompanied by parent and or guardian.]


MakerBar is a 501(c)3 NJ Non-Profit Organization.. All donations are tax deductible.....consider donating today...Help keep the H@ck3ry alive!


Interested in membership? Speak to one of our members about the many benefits of membership as well as the outstanding community that is Hoboken's MakerBar. Hudson County's one and only Hackerspace.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Printing

results.description:
9-a-side. 2 teams, 60min+ game. Pls arrive 10-15 mins early, to warm up and be ready to start at 11.00am.



ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.

If we have extra players we'll sub, or play 10v10. It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.


• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.


•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.


• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.


• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


The payment goes toward field permit & equipment. 

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.
results.name: Saturday Soccer 9v9 @11:00am Pier 5- Full-size goals, 60min+

results.description: We will meet up at New Park Pizza[masked] Cross Bay blvd at 11am kickstands up at 11.30 we will head out on the Belt Pkwy to the Cross Island pkwy to the Whitestone bridge then we will head down the Hutchinson River pkwy about 2 miles past the bridge there a Dunkin donuts rest stop on the Northbound side we will stop there to pick up any Bronx riders then continue to the Kensico Dam after exploring the Damm we will head Route 22. As soon as you pick up route 22 from the Kensico Dam, route 22 transforms from a congested, commercial shopping thoroughfare- laden with traffic lights and stop signs, (about 12 miles). Almost instantly you ride past and over the Kensico Reservoir on a 4 lane smoothly paved series of sweepers and bends. A few miles later 22 squeezes down to 2 lanes, as you go through some of the prettiest and wealthiest residential areas of Northern Westchester County. We will also stop to eat at some point probably Pats Deli will see what we decide. Must be able to maintain highway speed and please come with a full tank of gas any question feel free to call me at[masked] Lew
results.name: Kensico Dam/Route 22 Bedford NY

results.description:
This week's topic is the Fourth Noble Truth.

The Path to the End of Suffering

As we recognize there is suffering, dissatisfaction and unreliability in life, we can begin to accept that it is our attachment to and craving after impermanent things that causes our suffering.  We see that the things we hope will bring us stability and happiness just don’t live up to their promise.  Ultimately, we understand that the end of suffering will depend on changing our own states of mind and our views about our experience, not on relying on the impermanent things we desire.  So, how do we begin the work of changing our relationship to the suffering we find in life?

A common analogy used as a model for the Four Noble Truths is that of a physician treating illness.  We recognize the illness is present by the symptoms we experience, we see the cause of the illness and we understand the cure for the illness.  Finally we lay out a path of treatment.  That path, the Fourth Noble Truth, is called the Noble Eightfold Path.

The path, despite it’s name, is not a linear path of increased achievement, but really an interconnected collection of steps the we cultivate in the areas of conduct, mental development and wisdom.  We’ll briefly look at each of the steps:  Right Speech, Right Action and Right Livelihood (Good Conduct); Right Effort, Right Mindfulness and Right Concentration (Mental Development); Right Attitude and Right View (Wisdom).

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
